title: Update parse method parameters from HashMap to Map
body:
Referencing Map interface rather than HashMap concrete class allows
the methods to not be tied to a specific implementation of Map.

Updated for AParserWrapper, CommonSyntacticValidator, DMLParserWrapper, DmlSyntacticValidator, PyDMLParserWrapper, and PydmlSyntacticValidator, relating to the parse calls, so that a client calling the parser code can pass a Map reference rather than a HashMap reference. Also updated DMLScript, MLContext, MLOutput, and jmlc Connection to use Map references rather than HashMaps.

title: [SYSTEMML-294] Print matrix capability
body:
Can pass a matrix object to the print statement
- More complex things like print(X[1:10, 1:10]) do not work. The correct
  sequence of instructions is not being generated.
- Also Java style string concatenation does not work. print (x + X) does
  not work. (x=scalar, X=matrix).

I realize the matrix printing may not be the best format. Here is what it looks like for now:

For this DML code:

```
X = rand(rows=1000, cols=1000, min=0, max=4, pdf="uniform", sparsity=0.2)
Z = X[1:10,1:10]
print(Z)
```

![screenshot](http://i.imgur.com/CJ7qmpG.png?1)

@deroneriksson, @niketanpansare, @mboehm7 - thoughts?

Test cases were added for both dml and pydml where an imported script sources additional script(s) that also source scripts.

title: Inconsistency in descriptions
body:
Changes are all in descriptions. Didn't touch code.
- Corrected inconsistency of description and examples in argument. 
  - In the explanation of argument 'sv', example 1 and 2 contradicted the statement: "sum(sv) must be 1".  
  - Example 2 (sv = (0.25, 0.25, 0.25, 0.25, 0.25)) seems like a typo(?), because when `i == 5` in `parfor`, `T2` (line55) would be a zero column, so `P` (line57) would be empty.  
- Corrected location of 'sample.dml' in the example: From `algorithms/utils/sample.dml` to `./scripts/utils/sample.dml`.
- Added slightly more wordy explanations, as new users may try to learn dml from sample scripts like this one.

title: [SYSTEMML-617] Override default namespace for imported custom functions
body:
This patch with dml/pydml tests is intended to incrementally improve namespace handling to facilitate defining and reusing functions across multiple scripts.  It includes isolated changes to target a specific scenario where dependent functions (e.g., function1 internally calls function2 defined in same script) but are also imported by another script.  The change to StatementBlock was not required but included to help compare blocks when inspecting variables under IDE debugger.
Prior to this patch, the internal call would fail as described in [SYSTEMML-590] which is covered under 'testFunctionSourceNS'.  The other 2 tests were included to show this patch does not change expected behavior where imported custom function was not fully qualified (testFunctionWithoutNS) and internal custom function call without namespace ok when run directly (testFunctionDefaultNS).
A few built-in functions were also ran to verify built-ins still found in defaultns.

title: [SYSTEMML-604] Undefined function error message line, col, filename
body:
Previously, the following DML:

```
print("howdy");
a=foo();
```

produced error message with null filename and no line number or column number set:

```
Caused by: org.apache.sysml.parser.LanguageException: ERROR: null -- line 0, column 0 -- function foo is undefined in namespace .defaultNS
    at org.apache.sysml.parser.StatementBlock.isMergeableFunctionCallBlock(StatementBlock.java:201)
```

This update populates the filename, line number, and column number:

```
Caused by: org.apache.sysml.parser.LanguageException: ERROR: example.dml -- line 2, column 0 -- function foo is undefined in namespace .defaultNS
    at org.apache.sysml.parser.StatementBlock.isMergeableFunctionCallBlock(StatementBlock.java:208)
```

title: [SYSTEMML-577] Add High-Level "executeScript" API to Python MLContext.
body:
This adds the `executeScript(...)` function to the Python MLContext API, and in the process hides the need to use `registerInput(...)` and `registerOutput(...)` by allowing the user to pass in a dictionary of key:value inputs of any type, and an array of outputs to keep.

Example:

```
pnmf = """ // script here """
outputs = ml.executeScript(pnmf, {"X": X_train, "maxiter": 100, "rank": 10}, ["W", "H", "negloglik"])
```

title: Upgrade Apache Commons Collections to v3.2.2
body:
Version 3.2.1 has a CVSS 10.0 vulnerability. That is the worst kind of
vulnerability that exists. By merely existing on the classpath, this
library causes the Java serialization parser for the entire JVM process
to go from being a state machine to a turing machine. A turing machine
with an exec() function!

https://web.nvd.nist.gov/view/vuln/detail?vulnId=CVE-2015-8103
https://commons.apache.org/proper/commons-collections/security-reports.html
http://foxglovesecurity.com/2015/11/06/what-do-weblogic-websphere-jboss-jenkins-opennms-and-your-application-have-in-common-this-vulnerability/

title: [SYSTEMML-510] Generalized wdivmm w/ eps all patterns
body:
This patch with related tests extends the existing wdivmm operator by two patterns for four operands:
t(t(U)%_%(W_(U%_%t(V)+x))), and (W_(U%_%t(V)+x)%_%V, where x is a scalar (e.g., epsilon).

Supporting these patterns allows a DML script to contain epsilon similar to an equivalent R script that included epsilon to prevent divide-by-zero.

title: Using SystemML from Zeppelin in an end to end data analytics process
body:
This Notebook covers -

```
Ingestion of multiple Datasets from HDFS.
Exploration of the Data using Spark SQL
Merging of the data from various data sources for preparing data for building Model
Building Model using GLM.dml of SystemML
Using GLM-predict.dml for prediction using larger population
Relating the prediction back to original dataset
Visualization of Prediction using R libraries using SparkR.
```

Please note that this notebook uses a R interpreter for Zeppelin (https://github.com/apache/incubator-zeppelin/pull/208/commits) which is not part of main branch. So the SparkR paragraphs will not work if someone is using Zeppelin main branch. Alternatively one can use the branch related to this PR (PR#208). Also one has to have R and other relevant R packages installed separately on the same machine where Zeppelin process is running. the other R packages needed for the plots are googleVis, ggplot2, maptools, htmltools, knitr, repr (from http://irkernel.github.io/).

repo.name: incubator-systemml
repo.description: Mirror of Apache SystemML (Incubating)

repo.name: systemds
repo.description: An open source ML system for the end-to-end data science lifecycle

title: Example Zeppelin Notebook with End to End Data Analytics from Data Ingestion to Model Prediction using GLM
body:
This Notebook covers -
1. Ingestion of multiple Datasets from HDFS.
2. Exploration of the Data using Spark SQL
3. Merging of the data from various data sources for preparing data for building Model
4. Building Model using GLM.dml of SystemML
5. Using GLM-predict.dml for prediction using larger population
6. Relating the prediction back to original dataset
7. Visualization of Prediction using R libraries using SparkR.

Please note that this notebook uses a R interpreter for Zeppelin (https://github.com/apache/incubator-zeppelin/pull/208/commits) which is not part of main branch. So the SparkR paragraphs will not work if someone is using Zeppelin main branch. Alternatively one can use the branch related to this PR (PR#208). Also one has to have R and other relevant R packages installed separately on the same machine where Zeppelin process is running. the other R packages needed for the plots are googleVis, ggplot2, maptools, htmltools, knitr, repr (from http://irkernel.github.io/).

title: [SYSTEMML-456] parser code deduplication
body:
This is a first pass on the deduplication and cleaup effort between the visitors/listeners for the DML & PyDML generated by ANTLR4.
I've changed the grammars ever so slightly. A more thorough cleanup can follow, but will require significant changes to the Listeners that ANTLR4 generates; which i will leave for a future JIRA. 
There is a also a large chunk of code in the PydmlSyntacticValidator.java file that converts python built-in functions to it's DML equivalent. I or someone else can deal with this later.
There is a Jenkins [build](https://sparktc.ibmcloud.com/jenkins/job/SystemML-OnDemand/84/) in progress.

title: [SYSTEMML-495] Simplify SystemML Configuration Loading
body:
Currently, SystemML always looks for a configuration file in a default location (in the current directory), and will always emit a warning if it is not found.  Additionally, SystemML allows a user to supply a configuration file location.  In this latter case, SystemML will still attempt to read the default configuration file, emitting a warning if it is not present (which causes confusion), as well as the user-supplied file.  If both are loaded, the user-supplied file will be merged into the default configuration with an overwrite strategy.

Always looking for a default file, even when a file is explicitly supplied, causes confusion, and may create unintended side effects.  If a user explicitly supplies a configuration file, we should simply use that file, rather than attempting to also read an additional default file at the same time.  In order to provide backwards compatibility, if the user does not supply a file, then we should fall back to the default file location.  If that file is also not found, we should then fall back to the internal defaults.  Note that this means that the configuration settings of a user-supplied file will _not_ be merged with those of a default file, assuming both are found.

Additionally, in order to supply an additional configuration file, the `-config=path/to/file` flag has to be used, and it only works with the equals sign `=` present, which is unlike all other flags that use spaces.  Instead, we should support `-config path/to/file`.

title: [SYSTEMML-482] [SYSTEMML-480] Force Correct Normalization Of All Line Endings to Correct Unix-style Characters
body: This adds a `.gitattributes` file with a setting that will correctly normalize all files (other than those that are Windows-specific, such as .bat, .exe, etc.) upon checkin to the repo to have the correct Unix-style new line characters, rather than Windows-style carriage returns, while allowing for correct OS-specific new line characters while working locally.  Additionally, this setting will cause Git to correctly maintain the normalization for future commits.  As [seen during review](https://www.mail-archive.com/dev@systemml.incubator.apache.org/msg00254.html) of the first 0.9 release candidate, the lack of this normalization can cause major issues, and the issue is [confirmed in the official Git manual](https://git-scm.com/book/en/v2/Customizing-Git-Git-Configuration#Formatting-and-Whitespace).

title: [SYSTEMML-477] Updating the format of the metadata file JSON object
body:
Updating the format of the metadata file JSON object to have the commas placed at the end of the lines, rather than at the beginning of the lines.

Previously, the metadata files written would be formatted with the commas placed at the beginning of the lines, which was somewhat strange looking:

``` json
{ 
    "data_type": "matrix"
    ,"value_type": "double"
    ,"rows": 1
    ,"cols": 2
    ,"nnz": 2
    ,"format": "text"
    ,"description": { "author": "SystemML" } 
}
```

This change places the commas at the end of the lines, as follows:

``` json
{ 
    "data_type": "matrix",
    "value_type": "double",
    "rows": 1,
    "cols": 2,
    "nnz": 2,
    "format": "text",
    "description": { "author": "SystemML" } 
}
```

This applies to matrix and scalar metadata.  Since this is still valid (and perhaps better formatted) JSON, there shouldn't be any issues, and local testing supports this for writes and reads.

title: [Systemml-475] [WIP] Add Implicit Conversion Between Scalar Values and 1x1 Matrices
body:
**Work in progress**

---

Currently, any DML functions that require scalars will not accept 1x1 matrices.  Matrix indexing always returns a matrix, so a statement such as `A[1,1]` from the following simple example will return a single-valued matrix, even though it logically represents a scalar.  Thus, in order to use this value as a scalar, the `as.scalar(...)` function is required.

``` r
A = matrix(7, rows=10, cols=10)                                                                                                                
print( "A[1,1]: " + as.scalar(A[1,1]))  // 7
```

In this scenario, the required usage of `as.scalar(...)` can cause confusion, and can be viewed as a violation of SystemML's goal of hiding the underlying data representation from the user.

Additionally, many of the built-in functions, such as `rowVars(...)`, accept matrices without other requirements of dimensionality, and thus will accept a 1x1 matrix, yet will not accept a scalar value.  We should allow any such functions that accept 1x1 matrices to also accept scalar values.

``` r
a = 4
print("Row variances of scalar are: " + as.scalar(rowVars(as.matrix(a))))  // 0
```

In order to achieve this, we can add implicit casting between scalar values and 1x1 matrices within the parser during the validation stage as needed.

With this PR, the following can be done:

``` r
A = matrix(7, rows=10, cols=10)
print( "A[1,1]: " + A[1,1])  // 7
```

``` r
a = 4
print("Row variances of scalar are: " + rowVars(a))  // 0
```

---

**Note:  This is still a work in progress**, as there are likely additional fixes/improvements/changes that can be made, such as determining side-effects on other operations, or HOP rewrites such as removing unnecessary casting.

title: [SYSTEMML-217] Add New Unary Aggregates: Variance & Standard Deviation
body:
This introduces new "**_variance**_" and "**_standard deviation**_" unary operators to the DML language, including row and column variants for each: `var(X)`, `rowVars(X)`, `colVars(X)`, `sd(X)`, `rowSds(X)`, `colSds(X)`.  The implementation includes parser, HOP, LOP, runtime, and optimizer components.

The following provides an slightly more-detailed overview, and a full discussion can be found in the design document <sup>**[1]**</sup>:
- Adds `sd`, `colSds`, and `rowSds` built-in functions for standard deviation to the DML language.
- Adds `var`, `colVars`, and `rowVars` built-in functions for variance to the DML language.
- Creates a new `VAR` operation type for the existing `AggUnaryOp` HOP.
- Compiles the `sd`, `colSds`, and `rowSds` built-in DML functions to the square root of the variance via the `VAR` HOP type wrapped in a `OpOp1.SQRT` HOP type.
- Creates a new `Var` operation type for the existing `Aggregate` and `PartialAggregate` LOPs.
- Compiles the `VAR` HOP type to the `Var` LOP type.
- Creates new runtime opcodes: `"avar"`, `"uavar"`, `"uarvar"`, `"uacvar"`.
- Compiles the `Var` LOP type to new opcodes.
- Parses the new opcodes into runtime aggregate operators that use the `CM` runtime function with `Variance` type.
- Creates a new `VAR` aggregate type in the core unary aggregate library.
- Matches the runtime aggregate operators using the `CM` function of `Variance` type to the `VAR` case.
- Extends the core unary aggregate library with new variance functions for the `VAR` case.
- Adds logic for incremental aggregation of variances computed for multiple partitions. <sup>**[2]**</sup>
- Extends existing optimizer rewrites for column-wise and row-wise aggregation to cover row and column variances.
- Adds new optimizer rewrites to optimize row and column variance operations under certain conditions.

**[1]**: ~~_To be posted later once the JIRA project is set up._~~  This has been posted to [SYSTEMML-217](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/SYSTEMML-217).
**[2]**: The current implementations of `incrementalAggregate(...)` in `MatrixBlock` still need to be refactored, however, I've elected to postpone that to a future JIRA in order to limit the scope of this one.

cc @mboehm7

Below exception when use indexreturn.
com.ibm.bi.dml.parser.LanguageException: ERROR: test.dml -- line 2, column 0 -- Unsupported order parameter: 'indexreturn'
        at com.ibm.bi.dml.parser.Expression.raiseValidateError(Expression.java:413)

        at com.ibm.bi.dml.parser.DMLTranslator.validateParseTree(DMLTranslator.java:146)
        at com.ibm.bi.dml.api.DMLScript.execute(DMLScript.java:589)
        at com.ibm.bi.dml.api.DMLScript.executeScript(DMLScript.java:336)
        at com.ibm.bi.dml.api.DMLScript.main(DMLScript.java:195)
Exception in thread "main" com.ibm.bi.dml.api.DMLException: com.ibm.bi.dml.parser.LanguageException: ERROR: test.dml -- line 2, column 0 -- Unsupporte
d order parameter: 'indexreturn'
        at com.ibm.bi.dml.api.DMLScript.executeScript(DMLScript.java:348)
        at com.ibm.bi.dml.api.DMLScript.main(DMLScript.java:195)

my dml is:
A = matrix("1 2 3 4",rows=1,cols=4)
B = order(target=A,by=1,decreasing=FALSE, index.return=FALSE)
